Incident.Summary: WARRANT ARREST/ USE OF FORCE REPORT

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
WARRANT ARREST/ USE OF FORCE REPORT

Date: 9/21/2023
Time: 1739 hours
Location: Parkville MVA, 8966 Waltham Woods Rd, Parkville, Baltimore County, Maryland
Reporting Officer: Sergeant Felix Appiah #5622
Subject: BROOKS, MARIAH HAILIE, W/F, DOB: 07/01/1998

On September 21, 2023, at approximately 1739 hours, I, Sergeant Felix Appiah #5622, was working an extra-duty assignment at the Parkville MVA, located at 8966 Waltham Woods Rd, Parkville, Baltimore County, Maryland.

During my shift, I was assigned a Law Enforcement Agency (LEA) flag for an individual identified as Mariah Hailie Brooks, a white female born on July 1, 1998. The LEA flag was issued by the Baltimore County Sheriff's Department and pertained to a disorderly offense warrant with warrant #D-08-CR-20-060074-1.

At around 1746 hours, I contacted the Golden Ring Barrack to verify the validity of the warrant, which was subsequently confirmed. Subsequently, I informed the MVA Manager, Mrs. Sherrie K. Dyson, of the confirmed warrant, and Ms. Brooks was escorted to the back office.

Upon entering the office, I informed Ms. Brooks that the encounter was being recorded both audibly and visually. I explained the reason for her presence in the office, which was her active warrant. Ms. Brooks reacted with irritation and requested to call her father and inquire about the warrant's details. I informed her that the warrant was for disorderly conduct and the specifics of the warrant would be explained by the commissioner upon her arrival at the detention center.

Ms. Brooks expressed frustration, stating that the incident had occurred when she was 20 years old, and she was now 25. She made comments such as "You joking, you joking" and "No, no, no, no, no, no, no. I'm just gonna leave."

I reiterated to Ms. Brooks that she was not permitted to leave, as she had an active warrant for her arrest. She threatened to leave, stating, “No, no, no, no. I’m gonna leave. I'm not going to jail right now.” She then stood up from her chair and attempted to walk away.

Both the Parkville Manager, Mrs. Sherrie K. Dyson, and I made efforts to de-escalate the situation by speaking to Ms. Brooks in calm and reassuring tones. I provided a clear explanation for Ms. Brooks' presence in the office, including details about the active warrant and the necessary steps to resolve the issue. I patiently allowed her to call her father and advised him to come to the building.

In response to Ms. Brooks' uncooperative behavior, including verbal aggression, threats to leave before the matter was addressed, and an attempt to evade custody by standing up, we repeatedly requested her to calm down, but she remained unresponsive. Given the situation and the lack of practical alternatives to ensure compliance and maintain control, I employed a controlled restraint technique to place her hands behind her back. I secured handcuffs on Ms. Brooks' left wrist/forearm using a soft empty-hand technique.

Ms. Brooks actively resisted arrest when I began to employ the controlled restraint technique to position her left hand behind her back. She turned her body away from me, intentionally making it more difficult to secure her right hand. Ms. Brooks reacted angrily, exclaiming, "Why are you putting your Fucking hands on me like that? What the hell? I didn't do anything." She also resisted by refusing to turn her body around. Mrs. Dyson and I used verbal communication to address Ms. Brooks' frustration and anxiety, encouraging her to calm down and take deep breaths while assuring her that the warrant could be easily resolved. I provided verbal commands to calm down and, using the soft empty-hand technique, secured her right wrist/forearm and placed handcuffs on her right hand.

The use of force was promptly ceased once compliance was gained, and Ms. Brooks was handcuffed. Subsequently, she began to cooperate, and I explained the subsequent processes to her.

Drawing from my training, knowledge, and experience as a Maryland State Trooper, I recognized that using force was necessary to effect Ms. Brooks' arrest lawfully. The application of force was deemed necessary to prevent Ms. Brooks from attempting to evade custody, which could have posed a risk to the safety of all parties involved. The force used was reasonable, necessary, and proportional to the level of resistance encountered.

Ms. Brooks did not display any visible injuries, nor did she request or require medical treatment. The level of force applied to Ms. Brooks was minimal and did not result in any injuries. I did not display any visible injuries, nor did I request or require medical treatment.

Trooper Sampon #7515, of Golden Ring Barrack arrived at the scene and took custody of Ms. Brooks, transporting her to the detention center. I contacted the Golden Ring Barrack Duty officer, Corporal Neil Miranda # 2271, and informed him of the incident, notifying him that a use of force report would be completed.

My body-worn camera was operational during the incident.

All events occurred within Baltimore County, Maryland.
